thread.title: Bunnings may fail in the UK, expert claims | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Bunnings may fail in the UK, expert claims | Daily Mail Online

author: Max Margan
title: Bunnings may fail in the UK, expert claims | Daily Mail Online
text: Share this article Share 'They also intend to price match against online players. This is high risk as you could end up haemorrhaging margin day in, day out,' he said. 'In Australia you can probably do that because you don't have 200-plus online competitors. The retail landscape is quite different here.' He says Bunnings has missed a digital opportunity by not making online shopping available to its customers The pilot UK store for the DIY chain, owned by Western Australian-based company Wesfarmers, will replace the former Homebase store in St Albans. The new store, which is in Hertfordshire, is expected to focus largely on gardening products. According to a report from The Guardian, Bunnings bought the Homebase chain in a $700 million (£565 million) deal in 2016, and plans to convert all the stores. Wesfarmers chief executive Richard Goyder said the first few pilot stores will determine the timing of the conversion of the other Homebase stores. Bunnings' entry into the UK hardware market is sure to create some waves, with the country currently favouring B&Q and Wickes as their first choice for DIY products.
